title: Hunter shot deer…only for furious creature to get back up and gore him to death
text:
Hunter Thomas Alexander shot a deer…only for the animal to get back up and gore him to death with its antlers (Pictures: Roller Burns Funeral Home/KY3)

An elderly hunter shot a deer – only for the furious animal to get back up off the ground and gore him to death.

Thomas Alexander, 66, was prodded by the buck with its antlers after failing to kill it during a hunt in Yellville, Arkansas, on Tuesday.

Keith Stephens, from the Arkansas Game and Fish Commission said: ‘I don’t know how long (Alexander) left it there, but he went up to check it to make sure it was dead.

‘And evidently it wasn’t.

‘It got back up, and he had several puncture wounds on his body.’

Stephens added: ‘I’ve worked for the Game and Fish Commission for 20 years, and it’s one of the stranger things that’s happened.’

After being attacked, Alexander was able to get out his phone and call his family, who in turn alerted emergency responders.

He was rushed to hospital, where he later died, KY3 reported.

An autopsy will not be performed, meaning it will never be known whether Alexander died from the puncture wounds caused by the deer – or a heart attack caused by the shock of the attack.

Kim Killingsworth, whose son was married to Alexander’s daughter paid tribute to the later hunter online, writing: ‘My heart is broken as this world has lost a very beautiful man.

‘I didn’t know him real well myself, but knew plenty of him as my son-in-law always bragged about his father.

‘I did have a great opportunity to hunt and fish with Tom a couple of times and enjoyed hunting on his property several times.

‘He was a kind and sweet man and I know he was a wonderful Father and grandfather. He will be sorely missed.’

The Arkansas Game and Fish Commission says hunters should leave a deer alone for 30 minutes after shooting to make sure it is dead.

They also recommend watching a deer’s chest to establish whether it is still breathing.

It is unclear whether the deer that killed Stephens survived its injuries.
description: Thomas Alexander's chest was punctured by the deer he'd just shot during the vicious attack in Yellville, Arkansas on Tuesday
